extendedIngredients.name: arrowroot starch
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 tablespoon tapioca or arrowroot starch (or cornstarch)

extendedIngredients.name: chicken breasts
extendedIngredients.originalString: 3/4 lb chicken breasts, cut into 1 inch pieces

extendedIngredients.name: coconut aminos
extendedIngredients.originalString: 6 tablespoons gluten free tamari (or low sodium-soy sauce or coconut aminos for paleo version)

extendedIngredients.name: hoisin sauce
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 tablespoon hoisin sauce (use gluten free if necessary or omit for paleo version)

extendedIngredients.aisle: Nut butters, Jams, and Honey;Health Foods
extendedIngredients.name: raw honey
red bell pepper
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 red bell pepper, cut into bite-sized chunks

extendedIngredients.name: sea-salt
extendedIngredients.originalString: sea salt and black pepper as needed

extendedIngredients.name: water
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1/2 cup water, plus more as needed to thin out sauce
metaInformation: plus more  to thin out sauce

recipes.title: Healthy Cashew Chicken + Video

winePairing.pairingText: Chardonnay, Pinot Noir, and Sauvignon Blanc are my top picks for Chicken. White meat is typically paired with white wine as to not overpower the flavor of the meat, so chardonnay and sauvignon blanc are safe choices. Chicken prepared with a tomato sauce or certainly a red wine sauce can and should be served with a red like a pinot noir. The Chehalem INOX Chardonnay with a 4.1 out of 5 star rating seems like a good match. It costs about 13 dollars per bottle.

productMatches.title: Chehalem INOX Chardonnay
productMatches.description: INOXÂ® takes its name from the abbreviation of the French word for stainless steel, inoxydable. The wine was created differently from most Chardonnay you've had. We think we've succeeded in expressing the crisp, steely, and fruit-rich side that we love about some Old-World Chardonnays. What makes this possible is the use of exclusively Dijon clones, exceptionally well suited to Oregon's cool climate and exhibiting a richness that does not depend on oak. INOX screams of the hallmarks of a cool climate-brightness, pinpoint fruit, and explosive aromas and flavors. We intend INOX for a full range of use, from hot weather chilling to elegant dinner complements.Quintessential INOX, with lovely white aromas of gardenia and other flowers, peach, apricot, pear, pineapple, and green apple candy showing on the nose and palate; it shows a great balance with relatively low alcohol for the year and bright acid; the length is lovely and the weight rich, with a supple, silky texture; flavors linger, with cherry and peach accents. Very pleased.

recipes.instructions: In a medium bowl, combine all the ingredients for the sauce. Set aside.Season chicken with salt, pepper, tapioca starch and 1 tablespoon of sauce/marinade.Add oil to a wok or a large non-stick skillet over medium-high heat.Add the chicken and stir-fry for 5-6 minutes, or until the chicken is starting to brown.Toss in the broccoli and bell peppers and cook for 2-3 minutes, or until the vegetables are crisp-tender and the chicken is cooked through. Pour in the remaining sauce and add the cashews. Toss everything together and allow sauce to bubble and thicken. Season with salt, pepper or red pepper chili flakes as needed.Remove from heat and serve warm on a large platter or over zoodles (paleo), rice, quinoa or rice noodles. Sprinkle with sesame seeds and green onions if desired.

steps.step: In a medium bowl, combine all the ingredients for the sauce. Set aside.Season chicken with salt, pepper, tapioca starch and 1 tablespoon of sauce/marinade.
Add oil to a wok or a large non-stick skillet over medium-high heat.

Add the chicken and stir-fry for 5-6 minutes, or until the chicken is starting to brown.Toss in the broccoli and bell peppers and cook for 2-3 minutes, or until the vegetables are crisp-tender and the chicken is cooked through.
Pour in the remaining sauce and add the cashews. Toss everything together and allow sauce to bubble and thicken. Season with salt, pepper or red pepper chili flakes as needed.
Remove from heat and serve warm on a large platter or over zoodles (paleo), rice, quinoa or rice noodles. Sprinkle with sesame seeds and green onions if desired.
